SA,
-How often do you use NoSQL databases?
-When do you need to use them over normal SQL?

data.message: In my projects we don't have traditional databases anyways, but we use Redis for caching.

- As often as you need to.

- You'd typically need a NoSQL database when:
1)Your data is non-relational and strict schema makes no sense.
2)Your dataset happens to be huge; NoSQL tends to perform better due to denormalization. 
3)Your use case is served better by one of the 4 main NoSQL database types.

The 4 main types of NoSQL databases are:
1)Key-value
2)Document
3)Column-oriented
4)Graph 

Key-value stores are handy and simple. You can think of it a hashtable, where a unique key corresponds to a value.

A document database is similar to key-value stores except that the value field can be nested; it can contain other key-value pairs, and is stored in JSON.

A columnar store is typically useful when your data is large and/or distributed. An example would be HBase on Hadoop, where your data is distributed on the cluster.

Graph databases are handy when a graph model serves your use case better than traditional structured or semi-structured data models.

Just make sure if your application needs transactions, to make sure that your NoSQL database of choice has some support for Transactions and under what conditions and make sure your application can work with these conditions.
Using Mongodb for storing web attacks at shieldfy needed high preformance schema less json like store. Also using Redis in caching at the api side.
I had a project where my data are graphical in nature "think of nodes and edges" so while i could use a RDBMS I opted for a database that supports graph traversal natively.

As I might write that alot, relational/sql was made when disk space was expensive, the normal forms was for that goal. 

Make sure you don't use them very often in newer projects
Lots, redis mainly for caching, queues. Mongodb for backend. And an in-house system called arakoon (written in ocaml)
